conclusion: Understanding principles of refraction and how different colors of light are affected by a transparent material.
When a beam of light passes through a medium, it bends or refracts depending on the refractive index.
Different colors of light have different wavelengths and are refracted by different amounts.
Shorter wavelengths like violet are refracted more than longer wavelengths like red.
Refractive index \( n \) is the ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum \( c \) to the speed of light in the medium \( v \).
A higher refractive index means the light travels slower in the material.
The ball has an outer radius \( R \) and an inner radius \( \frac{R}{2} \).
A thin beam of red, green, and purple light is incident at \( 45^\circ \).
Green light (B) has its refracted ray tangent to the inner wall.
Since green light is tangent to the inner wall, its path suggests a specific refractive index.
Purple light has a shorter wavelength than green light and thus a higher refractive index.
Red light has a longer wavelength than green light and thus a lower refractive index.
The purple light (C) has the highest refractive index among the three colors.
The speed of purple light in the transparent material is the smallest.
